intro: Abutilon kotschyi, commonly known as the desert hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the Middle East and North Africa. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 3 meters in height, characterized by its rough, hairy stems and large, palmately lobed leaves. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers in shades of yellow, orange, or red, which bloom in summer. It is adapted to drought conditions, with deep roots and waxy leaves that reduce water loss. Abutilon kotschyi is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and resilience in harsh environments.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon kotschyi is primarily native to the Arabian Peninsula, including countries such as Saudi Arabia, Yemen, and Oman. It is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low precipitation. Its native distribution is largely confined to the southern and central parts of the Arabian Peninsula.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon kotschyi was mainly introduced to South Africa, where it has become naturalized in certain regions.
